Here is all I found about my mission. Ps I use Xbox 

Sorry circular orbit

Ok, well first off, if you are at 34 560m, you are not in orbit, so, unless you have rocket motors or parachutes to slow you, you will eventually be crashing down on Kerbin. Luckily you are in sandbox, so no biggie, two hours (after the crash) you will regain them (If they die, BC you came in too hot). If they don’t, when you land, you can recover them in the menu.. I am on Xbox as well, sadly it has not been easy getting help as much, so here I come.

The Advanced Grabbing Unit works just like docking ports, except you only need it on one vessel and it can attach to anything.

Launch the rocket like normal with the height of the orbit noticeably higher or lower than the target's orbit (20+ km height difference should do it). Select the station as the target and create a maneuver that brings your periapsis / apoapsis to the station's orbit. Drag it around your orbit until the two orange arrows meet and it says the encounter distance is less than 2km. Execute the node and timewarp until you're close. Select Retrograde when close and burn until your speed says zero. Then, use engine burning or RCS to move towards the station and grab it with the klaw.

The advanced grabbing unit (AKA The CLAW) can grab on to anything, so is one option.

Another option is just to send another vessel with a couple of empty seats (eg a Mk1-3 capsule with only 1 pilot on board) to rendezvous but don't dock.  Just get fairly close (100m or so will do) and then kill your relative velocity (clicking on the blue bit above the docking ball cycles it between Surface, Orbit and Target velocities), then EVA the crew and use their backpacks  (R to switch to RCS mode) to fly them across to the rescue ship.  

If you've not already got the hang of Orbital Rendezvous it's a skill you're going to need so this is a great opportunity to learn/practice it.  Plenty of forum threads and instructional videos around on how to do it and it is a tricky thing your head around to begin with but once you get the hang of it it's actually pretty easy. eg
